500 South Buena Vista St.

You missed your supper, boys.
Can I help you?
'Jack Kelly...?' Any of you boys know a 'Jack Kelly'?
Oh, dear me... dangerous? My files are in the rear -- this way, please.

Boys -- !

On me back, Mush.

That's right. It's an insult.
Runnin'.
Ya miss me, Weasel?

The usual.
scans the newspaper for a catchy headline; Race, Crutchy, the others wander up, doing the same. A commotion O.S.
Weasel glowers -- but wants to get back to business.         He backhands Morris who looks surprised.
Hold it.   Race -- spot me two-bits.
Another fifty for my friend here.

That and a lotta other things --
No kiddin'. How old are you, Les?
No good. Anybody asks, you're seven.
Younger sells more papes, Les --

... With this kid's puss and my God-given talent, we can easy move a thousand papers a week.

Replies.Reply: Sixty-forty.   Or I forget the whole t'ing.
The name of the game is volume, Dave.
First t'ing you gotta learn --
Some newsies got corners, see --
You're a natural, kid. You remind me of me -- and I can't say greater than that.
Page nine -- thank you, sir.
'Terrified flight from flaming inferno!' Thank you, much obliged --
Mine taught me not to starve.
I don't do nothin' the guys who write this stuff don't do. It ain't lyin' -- it's just improvin' the truth a little.
Hey, no drinkin' on the job --
Beat it -- the bulls!
Mistaken identity -- all micks look alike to these birds!
Sleeper!
No?   What're they doin' then?
The Refuge is this jail for kids.
I was starvin'. I stole some food.
Yeah, food. My name's Kelly, Jack Kelly, like I told you. Think I'm lyin'?
Because I escaped.
This big shot gimme a ride out in his carriage.
Nah. Teddy Roosevelt.    Ever heard of him?
You wouldn't kick me out without a kiss goodbye, wouldya, Medda?
This is David and Les. And this is the greatest star of the vaudeville stage today, Miss Medda Larkson, the Swedish Meadowlark.
Medda also owns the joint.
Okay if we hang here awhile, Medda?
They're out west lookin' for a place for us to live --
-- like this.
That's Sante Fe -- out in New Mexico? Soon's Pop finds us the right ranch, they're sendin' for me.
Maybe tomorrow we get a decent headline.
What I saw today, I gotta say your boys are born Newsies, Mr. Jacobs.
More when the headline's good.

Carryin' the banner.
How'd it go at the track, Race?
I ate, Mr. Kloppman, I...
... I was dinin' with a family.

I ain't payin' no sixty --
You bet -- I move right over to the Journal.
Why the jack-up, Weasel?

Nobody's goin' anywhere -- they ain't gonna get away with this!
One thing for sure. If we don't sell papes, then nobody sells papes.
Yeah, a strike -- good idea, Dave.
We go on strike, we're a union, right? Keep it comin', Dave --
Yeah, we organize -- we get all the New York Newsies to join us!
Another great idea! Any Newsie don't join with us, we soak 'im -- just like the trolley workers!

Dave's right again! We gotta think this through! Old man Pulitzer and Hearst and all them other rich geezers, they run this city. Do we really think a buncha streetrats like us would have a chance against people like them?
The choice has gotta be yours --
Pulitzer and Hearst have to respect the workin' boys of New York!
Keep it comin' -- what else.
We talk to 'em.
Then we soak 'em.

some... whattaya call 'em --

Me?
To Pulitzer?
Maybe the kid'll soften him up a little.
So's your ol' lady! Tell Pulitzer he needs an appointment with me!
-- So this snooty mug is sayin', 'You cawn't see Mr. Pulitzer, no one sees Mr. Pulitzer' -- real hoity-toity, you know the type --
Yeah, lookit me, I'm tremblin'.
My name really gonna be in the papers?
Not as long as you get it right --
You're movin' up in the world, Spot -- got a ocean view and everything.
It's a mouth with a brain -- and if you got half-a-one you'll listen. Tell 'im, Davey.
'Cause I'm tellin' you.

He was concerned about us bein' serious -- you imagine that?
At least somebody's got the right idea.

Cheezit -- the bulls!
The House of Refuge... my home-
How can I be sure the Delanceys stink -- 'cause that's how things work. An orphan gets arrested, Snyder gets him sent here to be 'rehabilitated' --
-- the more kids in the Refuge, the more money the city sends to take care of 'em, and the more Snyder can steal.
He's here alright.
Whattayasay, Tenpin.   You got a new guy, Crutchy --
That's Tenpin -- s'posed to get out last Christmas but Snyder keeps tackin' more time on his sentence --
Go get your hat, Crutch -- kiss Snyder good-bye.
Later, Crutchy -- get your stuff.
They hurt you...? Don't worry, we'll carry you --
Crutchy won't last in there...
Not in it.   On it.
Runnin' for governor. Showin' his concern, like all pols during elections.

Anyway, he's there. I see his fancy coach waitin' for 'im, so I sneaks on top of it. Teddy gets in and he's wavin' goodbye, and all the guys are wavin' goodbye, and Snyder's wavin' -- 'Good-byeeee, Colonel Roosevelt!' So just as we're goin' out the gate, I stands up and --
'Good-byeee, Warden Snyder!' It was in the papes and everything.
He only seen what Snyder wanted him to -- good food, everything the city pays for that Snyder usually steals.
Last year he was a hero.   This year he's a politician.
Look out -- !
Where's it say that...?
We ain't goin' away.   We'll never go away.
We'll do it up big, all right --
We got money, Medda.      Some, anyway.

Didn't wanna disturb nobody...
Your mom and pop are worried about me...?
You'd like it out there -- they got this big yellow desert and the air's real blue, see, from the sky, and the sun, it's bigger out there.
No.  No, it ain't...
Not that I been there or nothin'.
Sure... big family reunion.
Sounds like you and Dave don't do nothin' but talk about me.
Not that I blame you -- me bein' such an interestin' guy and all --
What'd I tell ya -- interestin', right?
Hey, Denton -- sit down front!
Carryin' the banner!
We come a long way but we ain't there yet -- and maybe it's only gonna get tougher from now on!
I personally wouldn't go that far, Race.
That's right -- start fightin' each other! Prove what the big shots say is true -- we're street rats with no brains and no respect for nothin' -- includin' ourselves!
Here's how it is: we don't stick together, we're nothin'. We don't trust each other, we're nothin'.
Carryin' the banner!
Hiya, fellas! Hey, Denton --
You two know each other?   Ain't that nice.
-- Like demandin' you give us the food you steal from us --
-- Last time wasn't no attempt, remember, Snyder? Me and Teddy Roosevelt wavin' bye-bye --
-- For my own good, right, Movealong? -- and for what Snyder kicks back to ya --
Very impressive. So where do they keep the trains in this station?
I heard of it. You win?
Heard of that, too.   I don't just sell ya papes, Joe.   Sometimes I read 'em.

Ring for my coach, willya?   It's past my bedtime --
-- or what? You'll send me back to the Refuge? I'll bust out again --
I told ya... I can't call off the strike.
And be a scab? Forget it --
You shouldn't'a done this, David.

I don't either -- I don't understand nothin' no more!
Just go!
So what's it git'cha?
We was beat when we was born.

Denton looked out for hisself just like I gotta do -- so save it.
Keep reading.
All them sweatshop kids are listenin' to me...?
The minute I show my face, I'm back in the Refuge.
Yeah... I'm thinkin' of Newsie Square full of kids...
-- Every workin' kid from every sweatshop in New York. We gotta get the word out -- let's go get the Newsies --

Sante Fe bound, Boots -- but not without givin' Pulitzer one last kiss goodbye --

Like I said, I don't transact business with no office boys.    We talk to old Joe hisself or we don't talk. Period.
I'd like to, Joe --

Hearst? Nah, it was yo --

And Hearst and them other owners?

Call it, Les!

-- the Delancey brothers!

Him?   Nah.

Sleep well, cowboy...?
Lift one finger... and you're right back in the Refuge.
I don't know how he got in here, Mr. Seitz -- but I'll take care of him, with pleasure. Just say the word!
Come again...?
'Trolley Strike Drags On for Third Week' -- this so-called headline drags on for infinity!
It's all Mr. William Randolph Hearst has, too -- see how he covers the strike!
Hearst is killing us in the circulation war -- and you give me headlines that would put a whirling dervish to sleep!
Steal Hearst's man -- offer him double what Hearst pays.
I created the World to be the best and I'll spend whatever it takes to --
What is that deafening noise?
make us number one! Well, we're going to cut costs, maximize profits -- and still beat the socks off Hearst --
I want to know how by tonight.
Seitz!   What in blazes is he talking about?
Of course I need to make more money!
Then Hearst undersells me and I'm in the poorhouse. Brilliant.
Wait. What  do the Newsies pay now -- fifty cents per hundred papers? If  you raised it to sixty cents --
-- then that, multiplied by forty thousand papers a day, seven days a week -- well, it would pay some of the bills around here.

Not necessarily. As newspapermen, Hearst and I would cut each other's throats to get the best of the other. But as businessmen -- and gentlemen -- we often agree on ways to keep down certain operating costs. If I know Willie Hearst, he's going to wish he thought of this himself.
If we do it, they'll all do it.
Give him whatever 'means' he requires, I want this nuisance over and done with.
Would the fact that this rally is organized by an escaped criminal be cause enough, Mayor?
A fugitive from one of your prisons, Mayor -- a convicted thief who's been at large for some time under the alias of 'Jack Kelly.' His real name is...?
You know Warden Snyder, don't you, Mayor? I believe you appointed him.
Not quietly -- I want an example made. I want this rabble he's roused to see what happens to those who dare to -- well, they should see justice in action.
By the way, Mayor, I'm having a few friends for cards that night -- newspaper friends, Willie Hearst, Gordon Bennett. Perhaps you'll join us -- we can talk about the coming election.
You know the boys, Mayor -- Mr.
Know what I was doing when I was your age? I was in a war. The Civil War.
People think wars are about right and wrong. They're not. They're about power. You know what power is?
Power means that I could see to it that you serve your full sentence at the Refuge. Or I could pull strings and have you free tomorrow.
I disagree. You're the spirit of the strike, without you, they'd fall apart in a few days.
Shut your mouth and listen !
You're going to do exactly as I say --
-- and be a fugitive who's pursued and caught and returned. I'm offering you a choice -- is that what you choose?
I'm not asking you to. All I ask is that you return to your old job -- as Newsie for the The World.
For a few days. Then the strike ends -- and it will end, boy, make no mistake -- and you can go wherever you want to buy a ticket.
You go back to the Refuge. Think it over in your cell. Let me know in the morning.
Kelly's down there. He should be back in jail.
Too good! Those illiterate guttersnipes couldn't have done this on their own. Somebody's behind this, trying to pull a fast one...
Tell Hearst I'm busy!
I'll settle it all right -- once and for all.
You're going to listen to me, boy --
We had a deal -- you broke it.
Neither am I. I can wait them out. It won't be me that's hurt.
I'm about to show you what power really is...
I have the police outside waiting to arrest you --
-- then I'll deal with that rabble in the street.
All the papers have an agreement...

I knew it. Whoever helped you print this lying rag is trying to break the strike, get the jump on the rest of us. Well, you're going to expose this backstabber to the other owners -- in exchange, I'll call off the police.
All right, all right -- just say the traitor's name. It's Hearst, isn't it? Say it! Say the name of the scoundrel whose press you used so I can make him the disgrace of the newspaper world!
Perhaps we can resolve our...
The news is slow, Chief, the Trolley Strike's all we got --
That's how he stole him from us.
Chief, you spend as much as you make fighting Hearst. That's why the paper's losing money --
Just the Newsies, Chief, I'll --
Says you need to make more money, Chief.
You mean the Newsies...? Charge the Newsies more for their papers?
Chief, if you do this, every Newsie we got will head straight for Hearst.
What about the other papers -- ?
I don't think they're just going to go away, Chief.
Get him inside.
Don't worry. He's got no place to go.
Those kids got out a pretty good paper, Chief.
It's time to talk.
Then I guess you talk.
With pleasure. You're fired.
We'll get a new headline writer, Mr. Pulitzer.
Oh, honey... look at that sweet little lamb...
There he is, officer -- do your duty!
You, Sullivan! Stop, I say!     You hear me, Sullivan?
You young miscreant! Wait'll I get you back to the Refuge!
You know this boy...?
You have a famous friend, this 'Jack.'... Do you know where he lives...?
Do you have a 'Jack Kelly' registered here? I wish to see him.
I have reason to believe he's an escaped prisoner. Possibly dangerous.
Sullivan, Your Honor -- Francis Sullivan. I would have caught him before now but --
Judge Monahan, I'll speak for this young man --
This boy's real name is Francis Sullivan; mother deceased; father a convict in the state penitentiary --
He is currently an escapee from the House of Refuge, where his original sentence of three months for theft was extended six months for disruptive behavior --
-- Followed by an additional six months for an attempted escape --
-- Therefore, I ask that he be returned to the House of Refuge --
-- And that the court order his incarceration until the age of twenty-one --
-- In the hope that we No! You can't do that!              may yet guide him to a No! Etc.                            useful and productive life.
After him!
What is the meaning of this? No one is allowed backstage -- you will leave at once! Out, out, out, out --
Kelly, where've you been, kid?
Welcome!
Don't ever own a theater, kid.
What have we here -- ? Aren't you the cutest little fella that ever was -- yes, you are --
This kid is good. Speaking as one professional to another, I'd say you got a future.
As long as you like -- now the lark must warble. Hey, you --
-- give my guests whatever they want.
'MY LOVEY-DOVEY BABY'... etc.
you one hundred percent. But I'm not running a union hall here --
It's not the money. I depend on the papers. They write good things about me, the customers flock here like sheep. They give me the pan, I'm the one who gets sheared.
They have the power to destroy people...
You are so young...
Got to be on Monday night.   I'm dark on Monday nights.
Don't thank me. Thank Mr.
Hiya, Newsies -- what's new?
You're all winners here tonight, Racetrack. Just being with you makes me feel kinda extra extra.
But you never know what life will bring. Over the years, I've developed quite an outlook --
And all kinds of people are always asking my advice, well, for instance --
You boys sing as sweet as songbirds.
Thank you, Boots. Would you keep it for me? For luck?
I'm afraid so, Race...
Unhand that boy this instant!
I said hands off the kid, you red-
If you're tired of beating up children, maybe you'd like to try a lady next.
Run, David, hurry --
You can't help him if you're in jail, too! You were right, David -- you've got to keep fighting them -- always.
Now go. Please.
Scabs!   Soak the scabs!   Etc.
My God...! What happened?
Mayer...!
That's for your birthday tomorrow!
That hand is not ready to work.
Who knows what's to eat where you're going?
We've been waiting dinner --
You made all this selling papers...?
Esther -- maybe David's partner would like to stay for dinner.
That many...?
You talk fine, Jack -- Sarah, get that cake your mother's been hiding in the cabinet!
I've had enough birthdays!    This is a celebration!
You work only until I go back to the factory! Then you go back to school, like you promised.
It will heal... they'll give me back my job... I'll make them...
David?   Time to come in now.
Ready or not, it can handle a broom.
Don't be too hard on your friend.
There.   You see?
A few things of mine and David's.
I don't know what's waiting for you in Santa Fe, but you'll always have family here.
What makes a headline good?
Did you sleep there?    Why didn't you wake us up?
Go up on the roof.
It's all getting so big. The family's very worried about the boys. And you, too.
The whole family...
David says you're moving away when the strike's over. To Santa Fe.
It's the same sun as here.
Guess your parents wrote you about it. Bet you can't wait to see them again.
David said you spent all your money to rent the theater.
We do not.
Are you...?
What is this?

It's Denton's story. 'The Dark Truth: Why Our City Really Fears the Newsie Strike, by Bryan Denton. Last night I saw naked force exercised against mere boys, the Newsies, who earn at best a few pennies a day. I wondered why so much, against so little -- '  David refuses to listen; he angrily steps out on the fire escape and stares off into the city. Sarah keeps reading to herself. What she reads disturbs her.
Les, come on -- you're supposed to be helping me today.
You... stupid... ape!
David!   Run -- get away!
David, no -- don't -- !
You're not going to run away.
You're wrong. You touched people you don't even know about.
Denton's story.
'In the voice of Jack Kelly, these children hear strength and pride.
Whatever happens, it's Jack's decision. He's the one in danger.
What -- ?
WATCH OUT!
WHERE?
THANKS.
BRING THOSE OVER.
TOO LOUD!   SOMEONE'S OVER US!
You don't have to run away anymore, Jack. You have a choice now.

Characters.Character: WELL WHO SAID YOU NEEDED ONE

Replies.Reply: AIN'T YOU GLAD NOBODY'S WAITING Jack starts down               UP FOR YOU?

Characters.Character: ALL MY THOUGHTS BEGIN TO STRAY

Replies.Reply: AND I'M ON THE TRAIN THAT'S BOUND FOR SANTA FE...
WHAT YOU'RE GIVEN?
DO YOU SWEAR YOU WON'T FORGET ME?
WOULD YOU LET ME COME AND STAY?
I'LL BE THERE...
Actual income, as well as projected income, against actual operating costs, as well as projected operating costs, produce a reduced marginality of profit which in turn --
I have several proposals. The first is to increase the paper's price --
Not the customer price -- the price to the distribution apparatus.
Very well. My next proposal --
A mere tenth of a cent per paper --
Mr. Hearst on the line, sir. Wants to know if you've read the Newsies' paper?
WE'RE AT THE POINT OF NO RETURN!
Hey, Weasel... Good ni-ight!
WE'RE AT THE POINT OF NO RETURN!
THEY THINK WE'RE NOTHING ARE WE NOTHING?
WE'RE A UNION JUST BY SAYING SO...
WILL WE HEAR IT?

Characters.Character: WHEN YA GOT A HUNDRED VOICES

Replies.Reply: SINGING, WHO CAN HEAR A LOUSY WHISTLE BLOW?
WORLD BUT HE DON'T OWN US!
What's going on?
What demands?
I'm Denton, New York Sun.   What's your name?
David.  As in David and Goliath?
You really think old man Pulitzer's going to listen to your demands?
Doesn't it scare you going up against the most powerful man in New York?
Keep me informed -- I want to know everything that happens.
What's important? A year ago I covered the war in Cuba -- charging up San Juan Hill with Colonel Teddy Roosevelt. A very important story.
Any objections?
Why don't you stop this -- ?
You're kids. They think   you'll get tired, or bored, or  maybe just too hungry. And with my   colleagues on the other dailies not  allowed to cover you --
-- They can just ignore you until you go away.
I'm working press tonight.
The only working press. As usual.
Aren't you Warden Snyder?
I'm Denton of The Sun. I've heard about your work with young people.
Is it Snyder as in 'snide'?
I'll pay the fines. All of them.
Meet me at the restaurant, all of you. We have to talk.
None of the papers covered the rally. Not even The Sun.
Because it never happened.
If it's not in the papers, then it never happened. The owners decreed that it not be in the papers, therefore...
I just came to tell you fellows goodbye.
Reassigned -- back to my old job as The Sun's ace war correspondent.
They could've blackballed me from every paper in the country. I'm a newspaperman, I have to have a paper to write for.
This is the story I wrote about the rally. I want you to read it at least.
' -- And that is what terrifies the powers-that-be, for they know our city thrives on the shame of child labor. Therefore, Jack Kelly's voice must be stopped, whatever the cost...
Damn good writing, isn't it?
They think if the Newsies can do it, why can't they? All they need is a leader.
You'd have help this time. I've been investigating the Refuge -- I know somebody who's going to be very interested in Snyder's little racket.
This war'll do for now.
How're you gonna reach all these people? No paper in New York will print anything about the strike.
A printing press. And no paper or printer is going to defy Pulitzer.
I thought you'd feel that way, Governor Roosevelt.
We brought the Warden over to say goodbye. Goodbye, Warden.
Governor Roosevelt's very grateful that this problem was brought to his attention. He'd like to offer you a lift, anywhere you like.
If it ain't Jack be nimble, Jack be quick.
What's this, Jackie boy?   Some kind of walkin' mouth?
So they told me. And what did they tell you?
You're right. Brains.
But I got brains, too -- and more than half-a-one. How do I know you punks won't run the first time some goon comes atcha with a club? How do I know you're in it to win?
Not good enough, Jackie-boy.   You gotta show me.
Nice try, pal. But that's just what I'm talkin' about.
Show me this strike ain't just some kids do-or-dare, then we'll talk.
So, ya showed me! Now I'll show you what Brooklyn can do --!
Where's me pitch'a?
Stop t'inkin' about yaself and let 'im read!
Any scab I see, I soak 'em -- period!
I don't care what they say -- some of us ain't made to just take it!
I say --
I say... what you say... I say!
Judge Movealong, ya honor, I object.
On the grounds of Brooklyn, ya honor!
You bummers is givin' me a headache.
Nachally  Spot Conlon is needed wherever  -- which right now is Brooklyn.   Some of my boys is worried,  I must give ear to their concerns  --
-- and reassure them.
Look... I'm seein' t'ings... tell me I'm seeing t'ings -- !
He sold us out! Ya dirty scab, I'll murder ya -- !
Take it   easy, Jackie-
Hey, Jack -- you ready?   I'm ready!
Who else is ready for stick-ball?
Cowboy!   Ya miss the joint?
The gimp?   I'll get him for ya.
You better move along, mister...
listens to MAYOR VAN WYCK, very nervous. Nearby is POLICE CHIEF DEVERY.
Of course the city is very concerned that this, uh, event doesn't get out of hand, but...
An escaped criminal...?
If this boy is a fugitive, then the chief can quietly arrest him and --
Arrest him at the rally?   But...
I'd be honored... thank you.
Chief, when you arrest this Kelly, you'd better go in force -- in case some of his misguided friends should start any trouble.
They're all yelling at me -- me!
I'm not taking the heat for this --
We can't just charge in and break it up, Mr. Pulitzer -- we got no legal cause.
Carryin' the banner!
No!    They asked for it -- etc.
Sarah stands next to Denton and Kloppman. Behind them, the door cracks and in slides Snyder. Kloppman sees him and whispers urgently to Denton, who starts moving after him.

Characters.Character: AND I STICKS OUT MY CHEST

Replies.Reply: AND I'M OFF TO THE RACES AGAIN!
'HELP ME,' HE CRIES, 'OR THEY'LL GIVE ME THE AX!' I SAYS, 'YOUR HONOR, YOUSE GOT TO RELAX.'  EVERYBODY!
The boys boo and hiss.
Awrise, awrise, court is now in session, Judge E.A. Monahan presiding.
Case of Jack Kelly, inciting to riot, assault, resisting arrest.
Any of you represented by counsel?
On what grounds?
I fine you each five dollars or two weeks confinement in --
Just move it along, Warden Snyder.
So ordered.   Next.
Pay the clerk. Next.

parked across the square. A Rough Rider opens the door and a man leans forward -- a glimpse of silk hat and walrus mustache as Teddy Roosevelt raises his walking stick in salute to Jack across the square.
